thread.title: Forget Harry Kane – Spurs fans hail Fulham BALL BOY for role in FA Cup win
thread.title_full: Forget Harry Kane – Spurs fans hail Fulham BALL BOY for role in FA Cup win

title: Forget Harry Kane – Spurs fans hail Fulham BALL BOY for role in FA Cup win

organizations.name: arsenal bournemouth burnley chelsea crystal palace everton hull city leicester city liverpool manche
city manchester united middlesbrough southampton stoke city sunderland swansea city tottenham hotspur watford west bromwich albion west ham forget

text:
Arsenal Bournemouth Burnley Chelsea Crystal Palace Everton Hull City Leicester City Liverpool Manchester City Manchester United Middlesbrough Southampton Stoke City Sunderland Swansea City Tottenham Hotspur Watford West Bromwich Albion West Ham Forget Harry Kane – Spurs fans hail Fulham BALL BOY for role in FA Cup win TOTTENHAM star Harry Kane gained the deserved praise after his hat trick against Fulham yesterday – but was there someone else who played an even more vital role? / Published 20th February 2017 
The away side comfortably strolled to victory in the FA Cup clash but some Spurs fans were quick to thank the Fulham ball boy for his role. 
Many saw the youngster as key to Spurs’ fast-paced attack which led to the first of Kane’s three goals. 
Kieran Trippier started the move with a quick throw – but all the speed and pace could have been lost had the quick-thinking ball boy not handed the ball over straight away. 
TWITTER/GETTY Spurs fans praised the Fulham ball boy for his role in Harry Kane's first goal 
Thankfully for Spurs fans, he did his job to perfection and the full-back immediately passed to the mercurial Christian Eriksen, who was able to fire a cross to Kane to slot home. 
Fans were quick to pay tribute to the man who started the move which helped them break the deadlock. 
“Ball boy with the pre, pre-assist,” one wrote. 
GETTY Kane was able to slot home soon after The fastest players to reach 60 Premier League goals Tuesday, 17th January 2017 HARRY KANE has gone past the 60-goal mark in the Premier League, but how many matches did it take him? 1 / 10 10. Ian Wright - 107 matches 
Another added: “That ball boy is better than Sissoko.” 
And a third commented: “Better distribution and awareness than either of our keepers.” 
The result sent Tottenham through to the quarter-finals, where another London Derby lies in store against Millwall – after their shock 1-0 win over Leicester . Related articles
